item.description:
​Join thousands of volunteers from throughout the watershed for the 14th Annual Earth Day Charles River Cleanup! Every year the Cleanup engages over 3,000 volunteers to restore and maintain along the Charles River and its tributaries by picking up trash and cleaning the riverbanks at over 100 sites from Milford to Boston. Last year Boston Volunteers joined others in this event in removing a total 40 tons of trash!

Cleanup supplies, snacks, and a free t-shirt are all provided! All you need to bring is your smiling self and a bottle of water. Restrooms will be on site as well.

Following the Cleanup everyone is invited to a volunteer appreciation picnic at the Hatch Shell with music, games provided by Knucklebones, and other fun!​

We'll be volunteering with the Esplanade Association in helping in the area around the Hatch Shell, where I'll have supplies and waiver sheets for everyone - meet me at the big registration table right in front of it (there'll be arrows and signage pointing to it - you won't miss it!):



 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

(Click here for larger map)

Spots for the cleanup fill up very fast; the Esplanade Association already has​ 350 volunteers, and it often meets its volunteer maximum of 600 people well before March 14th. Do take public transport as there is no parking around the Hatch Shell (you might find some expensive one on the Boston side by Arlington/Copley, and cross over the foot bridge to the Hatch Shell.)

​
The 14th Annual Earth Day Charles River Cleanup is organized by: Charles River Watershed Association, The Esplanade Association, Department of Conservation and Recreation, Charles River Conservancy, Emerald Necklace Conservancy, Green Decade Newton, Senator Will Brownsberger's Office, and Waltham Land Trust.


The Boston Volunteers

Big enough to deliver, small enough to care

Learn More: www.BostonVolunteer.org

Connect with us:
item.how_to_find_us: Meet at volunteer table by Hatch Shell (47 David G. Mugar Way, Boston)

group.name: Boston Volunteers. Big enough 2 deliver, small enough 2 care

item.name: Annual Earth Day Charles River Cleanup (by Hatch Shell)
